definition: lit. fight with one's back to the river (idiom); fig. to fight to win or die
the back of a body or object/to turn one's back/to hide something from/to learn by heart/to recite from memory/unlucky (slang)/hard of hearing
to be burdened/to carry on the back or shoulder
surname Shui
water/river/liquid/beverage/additional charges or income/(of clothes) classifier for number of washes
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
to fight/fight/war/battle

sentences.english: I was left with no choice but to fight my way out.
sentences.chinese: 我別無選擇，只能背水一戰。

sentences.english: The fleeing troops rallied and prepared for a last-ditch fight.
sentences.chinese: 潰軍重整旗鼓，準備背水一戰。

sentences.english: Can say, the price of direct let millet fight to win or die.
sentences.chinese: 可以說，這個價格直接就讓小米背水一戰了。

sentences.english: There is a kind of perseverance, called Kua.
sentences.chinese: 有一種勇氣，叫破釜沉舟，背水一戰。

sentences.english: Inevitably, a sort of bunker mentality quickly set in.
sentences.chinese: 一種背水一戰的心態不可避免地很快產生了。

sentences.english: Heparin was a desperate toss of the dice.
sentences.chinese: 使用肝素是背水一戰了。

sentences.english: There is a kind of courage, called the Rubicon, bite.
sentences.chinese: 有一種勇氣，叫破釜沉舟，背水一戰。

definition: fight to the death/desperate struggle
to be a cinch/in the bag/(of a person) confident of success
to surmount all difficulties (on the way to success) (idiom)/abbr. for 過五關斬六將|过五关斩六将[guo4 wu3 guan1 zhan3 liu4 jiang4]
lit. to sleep on brushwood and taste gall (like King Gou Jian of Yue 勾踐|勾践[Gou1 Jian4]), in order to recall one's humiliations) (idiom)/fig. to maintain one's resolve for revenge
the content of a conversation/words/remarks
lit. the salted fish turns over (idiom)/fig. to experience a reversal of fortune
to be drowned (figurative and literal)

Feast at Hongmen/(fig.) banquet set up with the aim of murdering a guest/refers to a famous episode in 206 BC when future Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] escaped attempted murder by his rival Xiang Yu 項羽|项羽[Xiang4 Yu3]
equestrianism/horsemanship
hoodlum/bad guy
indirect, psychological method of getting sb to do as one wishes (e.g. questioning whether they are up to the task)
to be determined to win (idiom)
to die in battle (idiom)
to charge and break through enemy lines
to be reluctant to give up a post
seize every minute and second (idiom); not a minute to lose/every moment counts
